channel.title: Using A String

item.title: Using A String
item.dc:creator: @Java_Is_My_Bitch Java Is My Bitch™
item.description:
@Java_Is_My_Bitch wrote:

[quote=“bakatool, post:3, topic:168111”]why should JP be a string if its a integer it is set to playerId of JPZ

if you type ::command javaismybitch thats already a string. So you can split it by command.split(" ") and get each args[].

you want? a command that works of playername? than you can do that.

if(command.contains(playerName)) {
…
}

if command contains the playername or startsWith whatever you want. aka your name than you can use it?

also

String JPZ = command.substring(6);
int JP = PlayerHandler.getPlayerID(JPZ);
client j = (client) server.playerHandler.players[JP];

j.playerName = His playername now its his instance which is a string[/quote]

I get what you mean i read it like three times.

The command is called command.

The string i type after that is the name, i want the string JP to be.

Can’t i just put:

public String PersonsName = “”

When i’m typing up the command.

Can’t i just put this:

PersonsName = “command.substring(6);”

Also:

String JPZ = command.substring(6);

Since i want the name that is being typed after.

So in total, i would have this:

String JPZ = command.substring(6); PersonsName = command.substring(6); int JP = PlayerHandler.getPlayerID(JPZ); client j = (client) server.playerHandler.players[JP];

So then under the process, let’s say i want to teleport everyone EXCEPT the person in the String.

if(!playerName.equalsIgnoreCase(PersonsName)) {
teleportToX = X;
teleportToY = Y;
}

Will that work?

Read full topic

item.title: Using A String
item.dc:creator: @bakatool bakatool
item.description:
@bakatool wrote:

why should JP be a string if its a integer it is set to playerId of JPZ

if you type ::command javaismybitch thats already a string. So you can split it by command.split(" ") and get each args[].

you want? a command that works of playername? than you can do that.

if(command.contains(playerName)) {
…
}

if command contains the playername or startsWith whatever you want. aka your name than you can use it?

also

String JPZ = command.substring(6);
int JP = PlayerHandler.getPlayerID(JPZ);
client j = (client) server.playerHandler.players[JP];

j.playerName = His playername now its his instance which is a string

item.title: Using A String
item.dc:creator: @Java_Is_My_Bitch Java Is My Bitch™
item.description:
@Java_Is_My_Bitch wrote:

Can i use a String to input it into:

if(!playerName.equalsIgnoreCase(“StringName”)) {
//Whatever?
}

–

What i wanted to do is this:

public String JP = “”;

I use a command on a player, and their name gets assigned to the string:

String JPZ = command.substring(6);
int JP = PlayerHandler.getPlayerID(JPZ);
client j = (client) server.playerHandler.players[JP];

JP = “JPZ”;

Would that work?

if i typed:

::command javaismybitch

Will the string now be:

JP = “javaismybitch”;

?

Also if that somehow works, could i use it like this afterwards:

if(!playerName.equalsIgnoreCase(“JP”)) {

}

Just a thought i’m wondering about, if anyone can answer it, i would greatly appreciate it.

Read full topic
